text: See discussions, stats, and author profiles for this publication at: https://www.researchgate.net/publication/317551178

Clustering Seismic Datasets for Optimized Facies Analysis Using a SSCSOM
Technique

Clustering Seismic Datasets for Optimized Facies Analysis 
Using a SSCSOM Technique

H. Hashemi* (Institute of Geophysics, University of Tehran), P. de Beukelaar (SoleGeo), B. 
Beiranvand (Research Institute of Petroleum Industry), M. Seiedali (Iranian Offshore Oil 
Company)

The derivation of seismic facies codes needs extensive knowledge and selection of seismic attributes. Seismic 
facies analysis is aimed to find the natural grouping in a data set based on the character of the recorded seismic 
response. In a common unsupervised facies analysis algorithm it is found that each group of seismic trace 
segments are related to a particular depositional environment. Most of the previous attempts in seismic facies 
analysis were in application of unsupervised algorithms like SOM.Control in unsupervised clustering results is 
limited by the number of final clusters (facies codes) that is mostly fixed by predefined and existing lithofacies 
codes or wavelet shapes. The idea is having user-intervention and interpretation in the per class posterior 
probability space. Unlike supervised methods in which the labeling is done in the input space by picking, semi-
supervised methods are aiming to accept/reject clustering on the basis of interpretation in the near well space.

The concept of facies is purely defined by its geological description, but “seismic facies” refer to a 
seismic description of depositional environment limited to a seismically thin interval (between 
successive interpreted horizons) until the limit of its maximum resolution. We combine the 
best of these two worlds by a S(emi) S(upervised) C(onstrained) S(elf) O(organising) M(ap) 
technique. The derivation of seismic facies codes needs extensive knowledge and selection of 
seismic attributes. Seismic facies analysis is aimed to find the natural grouping in a data set 
based on the character of the recorded seismic response. On the other hand, there is 
continuous debate between geophysicists and geologists for construction of facies maps. The 
challenge also exists in the correct use of implemented algorithms for facies analysis in 
commercial packages. E.g. Petrel (TM of Schlumberger) uses a geostatistical algorithm with 
an optional seismic trend to propagate well facies to 3D space while Stratimagic (a TM of 
Paradigm) relies on a clustering algorithm solely on seismic data with a possible cross check 
with wells. There is no “best approach” as these and also other commercial packages exist 
and all may provide improved results by continuous research efforts and depending on the 
type and quality of available data.  
Data clustering is the process of dividing data elements from original images into classes or 
clusters so that items in the same class are as similar as possible, and items in different 
classes are as dissimilar as possible. Depending on the nature of the data and the purpose for 
which clustering is being used, different measures of similarity may be used to place items 
into classes, where the similarity measure controls how the clusters are formed. Some 
examples of measures that can be used as in clustering include distance, connectivity, and 
intensity. 
Marroquín et al (2009) used an unsupervised clustering analysis toolbox in a completely data 
driven approach that requires no external information e.g. well logs to guide the seismic-trace 
classification. After careful seismic attributes selection and redundancy reduction by 
Principal Component Analysis (PCA), well facies control compared to seismic ones is still 
the only final validation or calibration.  
Redundant seismic attributes especially in the time-frequency domain represent an obstacle 
for easy classification and interpretation. In order to overcome the problem of using seismic 
attributes redundancy in seismic facies analysis, Hashemi (2012) proposed a measure named 
Full Band Width Illumination (FBWI) as an indicator for detecting an acoustic blanking zone 
to be interpreted as a gas-induced absorption in reservoir studies. The proposed method is a 
fast qualitative and even quantitative way for finding areas as leaking, sealing and fluid 
migration pathways. The proposed method is unsupervised and is based on the fuzzy GK 
clustering algorithm. 
Zeng (2004) introduced Geomorphology as a seismic facies indicator coming from well 
facies that had so far received little attention for automated facies analysis. In recent years, 
the use of a differential geometrical concept e.g. curvature as a geomorphological based 
seismic attributes implicitly affects seismic object detection routines.  
In the current paper, well facies maps are additionally used for training seismic facies and 
constraining the input seismic attribute values. Special attention had been given to an overall 
upgrade of well data quality and consistency before producing the well facies maps.

Workflow of semi-supervised constrained seismic facies analysis 
In supervised seismic pattern recognition applications, the prior probabilities are not 
determined. Instead even class frequencies will be used. An example is the fault/non-fault 
problem, with just two class picks only. The lack of spatial-temporal prior estimates may 
damage the output severely regardless of the used classifier algorithm e.g. Artificial Neural

Networks (ANN) or Support Vector Classifier (SVC) as discussed by Hashemi (2010). 
Supervised schemes are promising and highly applicable for object detection algorithm in 
seismic interpretation, buttheir implementation to multi-class problem of facies usely remains 
tricky. Spatial constraints from well logs are used here to limit geologically unlikely facies 
changes in seismic attribute clustering i.e. traditional unsupervised seismic facies analysis. 
The constraints are lithofacies maps in specific time intervals derived from wells using the 
nearest neighbourhood algorithm. Feature selection enables firstly dimensional reduction in 
the seismic attributes space.  Further reduction is obtained by a combination of linear and 
kernel (non-linear) PCA. The new attributes give better separation and are more distinctive 
for defining boundaries between lithofacies codes. The clustering in this approach is a Self 
Organizing Map (SOM) algorithm. “Number of clusters” is one of the most important 
parameters in clustering. When there is no initial knowledge about possible lithofacies codes, 
the interpreter shall run a number of different classifications with different number of clusters 
to evaluate the effect of each computation on the final posterior probability map.  
Semi-supervised methods were introduced in this work and the algorithm shows to be 
superior in most cases to unsupervised and supervised methods. An application for seismic 
noise reduction is reported by Hashemi et al. (2008). Unlike supervised methods in which the 
labelling is done in the input space by picking, semi-supervised methods are aiming to 
accept/reject clustering on the basis of interpretation in the near well space. This iterative 
process turns out to be an important factor in more robust clustering and the creation of 
lithofacies maps from seismic attributes and optimized seismic facies maps for geological 
interpretation. The workflow of proposed method is drawn in Figure 1.

Figure 1 Workflow of semi-supervised constrained seismic facies analysis.

Figure 2 shows (a) final seismic facies, (b) input lithofacies and (c) and (d) important seismic 
geomorphological maps. A carbonate interval was interpreted on marine seismic data with an 
interpreted NW-SE flooding surface as made visible in Fig. 2(d) lower thickness of the 
interval has red colour, while thickest parts of the interval are blue. The green zone is in 
between. The lithofacies map in Fig. 2 (b) does not distinguish sandstone (orange) and 
limestone (blue) with a geomorphological acceptable limit or border. Applying the method on 
real data, the proposed lithofacies borders of sandstone-limestone were changed. The more 
likely shapes made visible in both thickness and amplitude-inversion meta-attribute are now 
new region borders proposed for limestone.
Figure 2 . a) Final seismic facies map, b) Lithofacies map, c) Amplitude-inversion meta-attribute,
Added value by use of pre-stack data conditioning and log upgrades

If also state-of-the-art pre-stack data conditioning is applied to the seismic data and an upgrade of 
calibration logs were made as well, even more accurate and reliable results could be obtained. 
We computed attributes to analyze the flatness of specific events associated to seismic horizons and 
assessed seismic health with recent pre-stack analyses software running on a high-performance

hardware platform.  Beyond more accurate predicting of the seismic facies with better imaged data 
after stack, as demonstrated, we might still have the potential of considering the full data content, 
including the preservation of full wave propagation phenomena and/or elastic/ fluid parameters that 
otherwise would have been lost in the stacking process. Analyzing pre-stack gathers added more value 
to our multi-class classification experiment. 
Special attention had already been given to an overall upgrade of well data quality and consistency 
see e.g. de Beukelaar et al. (2001) as carried out before seismic inversion and basement mapping. This 
well log upgrade is also relevant for producing more accurate well facies maps. More in particular 
also velocity and density logs were upgraded, that means made more accurate calibrations by 
integration with check shot and VSP data from top to bottom after a priori integration with cuttings 
and core descriptions to remove acquisition and measurement errors as a rigorous correction of the 
logs.

In a common unsupervised facies analysis algorithm it is found that each group of seismic trace 
segments are related to a particular depositional environment. Most of the previous attempts in 
seismic facies analysis were in application of unsupervised algorithms like SOM.Control in 
unsupervised clustering results is limited by the number of final clusters (facies codes) that is mostly 
fixed by predefined and existing lithofacies codes or wavelet shapes.  
Supervised methods are most often successful in binary (two class) classification with no ability of 
intervention on posterior probability space, whereas seismic facies analysis is a multi-class 
classification experiment. Proposed semi-supervised method constrain both prior (with lithofacies 
maps) and posterior probabilities (with geomorphological data/model driven maps). Finally also pre-
stack data conditioning and more rigorous log QC resulted in an increasingly accurate and reliable 
result of the obtained 3D depositional environment models. 
Pre-stack data-analyses can also be used for dense and accurate velocity screening and conditioning of 
gathers for better seismic facies calibration of the proposed semi-supervised pattern recognition 
technique and such create new data sets and maps that may contain the possibility of further 
classification techniques directly applied on the pre-stack seismic data gathers.

We are grateful of Research Petroleum of Oil Industry (RIPI) and Iran Offshore Oil Company (IOOC) 
for provision of data and permission to publish the results.
